select1.label: Q1. Do you administer injectable Artesunate?
select1.hint: Child ≤ 20kg: Give Artesunate 3mg/kg Body Weight IV or IM at admission (time = 0), then at 12 hour and 24 hour, then once a day is the recommended treatment. For adults and children >20kg: Give Artesunate 2.4 mg/kg Body Weight (BW) IV or IM at admission (time = 0), then at 12 hour and 24 hour, then once a day is the recommended treatment.

select1.label: Q2. Do you administer Intramuscular Artemether?
select1.hint: The initial dose of artemether is 3.2/kg BW by intramuscular injection (anterior thigh). The maintenance dose is 1.6mg/kg BW daily. Administer full course of ACTs when patient can tolerate orally

select1.label: Q3. Do you administer Intravenous Quinine?
select1.hint: Child: Give 20 mg/kg of quinine dihydrochloride salt as loading dose diluted in 10 ml/kg of 4.3% dextrose in 0.18% saline or 5% dextrose over a period of 4 hours. Then 12 hours after the start of the loading dose, give 10 mg salt /kg infusion over 4 hours. Then every 8 hours until when patient is able to take orally. Then give a full dose of recommended ACT.Adult: 20 mg/kg of quinine dihydrochloride salt to a maximum of 1.2gm (loading dose) diluted in 10 ml/kg isotonic fluid by intravenous infusion over 4 hours then, 8 hours after the start of the loading dose, give 10 mg/kg salt to a maximum of 600 mg over 4 hours every 8hours till patient is able to take orally. Then give a full dose of recommended ACT.Adult: 20 mg/kg of quinine dihydrochloride salt to a maximum of 1.2gm (loading dose) diluted in 10 ml/kg isotonic fluid by intravenous infusion over 4 hours then, 8 hours after the start of the loading dose, give 10 mg/kg salt to a maximum of 600 mg over 4 hours every 8hours till patient is able to take orally. Then give a full dose of recommended ACT.

select1.label: Q4. Do you administer Intramuscular Quinine?
select1.hint: 20mg/kg (loading dose) diluted to 60mg/ml with sterile water on the anterior thigh, then maintain on 10mg/kg 8hourly until patient can tolerate orally

Q1. Is there a designated store for health commodities?
Is the storage space clean?
Are there signs of pest infestations?
Are the shelves clean and free of dust?
Are boxes (cartons) kept on pallets, shelves, or cupboards?
Are there smoke detector(s) and fire extinguisher/sand bucket in the premise?
Are facility staff trained on the use of firefighting device?
Q1. Are commodities arranged based on FEFO (first expiry first out) policy?
Q2. Are the commodities in a dry, well-lit, and well-ventilated storeroom, out of direct sunlight?
Q3. Are cartons arranged with arrows pointing up and with identification labels, expiry dates, and manufacturing dates clearly visible?
Q4. Is there a functional air conditioner in the store?
Q5. Are expired and damaged products stored separately? (ask the staff to explain the process of disposal and check related documents)
Q6. Are flammable products stored separately and away from other products?
Q7. Are cold storage equipment available, functional and used in the facility?

input.label: Please state the functional and available cold storage facilities.

select1.label: Q8. Are commodities stored under appropriate storage conditions as indicated on the label?
Q9. Are there functional thermometers, and/or remote data temperature reader (RDTR) available in the store?
Q10. Are there updated temperature logs in the store?
Q11. Are commodities subject to visual inspection periodically?

input.label: What is the schedule?

select1.label: Q12. Do any of the vaccines indicate VVM (vaccine vial monitor) changes?

input.label: Kindly specify the type of changes

select1.label: Q1. Does each product have an inventory control card (or stock card)?

Q4. Is physical count of all stocks conducted regularly, as per defined schedule?

input.label: Note the date of last physical count.

select1.label: Q5. Is there any other LMIS (e.g. software, Ledger) tool for inventory management besides the ICC/stock card?

Q1. Does the facility personnel know how to calculate Average Monthly Consumption (AMC)?
Q2. Does the personnel know how to calculate Quantity to Order (QTO)?
Q3. Does the store personnel know how to calculate Emergency Order Point (EOP)?
Q4. Is the Emergency Order Point(EOP) used for placing emergency requests?
Q1. Are all deliveries for health products received by a store personnel or health worker?
